title.narrative: World Vision CORE Project fas II
World Vision CORE Project phase II

description.narrative: Omprogrammerade medel för att lindra konsekvenserna av covid-19 Projektet syftar till att öka möjligheten för produktiv sysselsättning utanför jordbruket, för ökad inkomst för kvinnor och unga i distrikten Nyamasheke och Rusizi. Detta genom att öka företagande och affärsverksamhet utanför jordbruket för målgruppen, genom förbättrat företagsklimat, ökad tillgång till finansiella tjänster samt informations- och kommunikationsteknologi. Särskilt fokus kommer att läggas på utveckling och av värdekedjor inom honungsproduktion och sömnad för att göra dem mer inkluderande av målgruppen.

Reprogrammed funds to mitigate the impact of COVID-19 The project aims to contribute to productive off-farm employment in order to increase household income for women and youth in Nyamasheke and Rusizi districts. The project contributes to increased off-farm entrepreneurship and market oriented businesses for the target group, through enhanced enabling environment for cooperatives and businesses, increased access to financial services and information and communication technologies. Special focus will be placed on developing the value chains in honey production and tailoring to make them more inclusive of for target group.

tag.narrative: 1.4 - By 2030, ensure that all men and women, in particular the poor and the vulnerable, have equal rights to economic resources, as well as access to basic services, ownership and control over land and other forms of property, inheritance, natural resources, appropriate new technology and financial services, including microfinance.

1.4 - Senast 2030 säkerställa att alla män och kvinnor, i synnerhet de fattiga och de utsatta, har lika rätt till ekonomiska resurser, tillgång till grundläggande tjänster, möjlighet att äga och kontrollera mark och andra former av egendom samt tillgång till arv, naturresurser, lämplig ny teknik och finansiella tjänster, inklusive mikrokrediter.
5.b - Enhance the use of enabling technology, in particular information and communications technology, to promote the empowerment of women.
5.b - Öka användningen av gynnsam teknik, i synnerhet informations- och kommunikationsteknik, för att främja kvinnors egenmakt
8.5 - By 2030, achieve full and productive employment and decent work for all women and men, including for young people and persons with disabilities, and equal pay for work of equal value.

8.5 - Senast 2030 uppnå full och produktiv sysselsättning med anständiga arbetsvillkor för alla kvinnor och män, inklusive ungdomar och personer med funktionsnedsättning, samt lika lön för likvärdigt arbete.

title.narrative: WORLD VISION CORE PROJECT PHASE II
World Vision CORE Project phase II

description.narrative:
Examples of results/outputs under each outcome based on the annual narrative report. OUTCOME 1: Increased off-farm entrepreneurship and market-oriented businesses among women & youth
As indicated in the Graph above, VSLAs had over USD 1.1 million in savings as compared to USD 857,000 provided out in loans. WV report that this is indicating that members are servicing their loans well as well as continue to lending to their fellow members, thus a multiplier effect reflected as well as sustainability of the model guaranteed. However, the loans given out in the last half of FY 20 decreased due to the effects of COVID19 pandemic. Although savings were maintained, loans requested were low compared the previous year of implementation. COVID19 Rescue Plan WV reports that the interruption of economic activities country-wide and in project operational areas in particular has affected project beneficiaries in a number of ways including the burden of food insecurity among other vulnerabilities. The restrictions of movement, transport, and market operations have negatively impacted small businesses especially the ones engaged in cross-border businesses. The impact for vulnerable households range from loss of food security and nutritional issues to job and income losses and heightened probability of falling into poverty or chronic poverty. WV reports having supported 6,954 project beneficiaries; 3894 (56%) from Nyamasheke and 3060 (44%) from Rusizi whose businesses were most affected by COVID- 19 with working capital of about USD 52 to be able to revamp their businesses and to be able to provide for their families. WV states that reports show that 49% of the cash received by project beneficiaries during COVID-19 crisis was invested to resume/re-enforce their existing but struggling businesses which are the main sources of household incomes for their survival. About 27% of cash transferred to beneficiaries were able to pay their VSLA loans and resumed their businesses, and 19% more the ones doing cross border trade bought product assets for future resale to reinvest in their businesses once border resume full operations, and 5% opened new ventures and used half of the funds received to spend on immediate needs including food for survival purposes. Although the pandemic has far reaching negative impact on incomes sources of women and youth, these cash transfers have served as a boost for reopening small scale businesses and slowly resume normal operations. This enabled them to provide for their families especially during time COVID19 crisis. The project also constructed 10 hand washing stations at market places in both Rusizi and Nyamasheke districts. In Nyamasheke district, the 5 constructed facilities will mitigate the risk of COVID-19 of the 27,500 people that go this market every week. For Rusizi district, the 5 hand washing stations facilitate 15,555 people to easily access the markets. OUTCOME 2: Improved business competitiveness for Tailoring and Honey value chains through the Market Systems Approach.
WV conducted a market system diagnosis to analyze whether the two selected value chains (Honey and tailoring) are still relevant and suitable to improve the livelihoods of women and youth of Ubudehe Categories I & II. During FY 19/20, the project identified and selected the two honey and one tailoring lead firms (LF) to facilitate Micro, Small and Medium Enterprises (MSMEs) managed by women and/or youth in Nyamasheke and Rusizi districts to address identified honey and tailoring value chains constraints and provide commercially viable market based solutions. Two honey companies namely ABDC Ltd and The Apiary PTE Ltd and one (1) tailoring company called Ineza Textile Industry Ltd were selected and signed partnership agreements with WVR as LFs effective September 2020. Out of 789 members identified to be involved in honey value chain, 50 % are women and youth (women 40%, youth 10%) and 50% are men. Although the main target groups for the project are women and youth from Category 1& 2 of Ubudehe, due to Rwanda social norms, culture and mindset of rural community members, beekeeping activity in Rwanda was generally reserved for old men and it was like a taboo for women and youth to be involved in this sector. 15 out of 562 members from tailoring groups enrolled in MSA, 88 % are women and youth (women: 50% and youth: 38%). Unlike honey value chain dominated by men, tailoring on another hand is way above dominated by direct project target groups with the intention of empowering women and youth to benefit more from this value especially capitalizing on made in Rwanda program in tailoring and the banning of second hand clothes and improve their incomes as opposed to being the majority participants in the sector without better and reliable income from the value chain. During FY 19/20, the price of collected honey has increased from 2,650 Rwf/kg (Season 2019) to 3,300 Rwf/kg (Season A 2020) equivalent to 24.5% as reported price increase as reported by ABDC Ltd, one of CORE project LF partner to quality improvement (ABDC Ltd, September 2020 monthly report). Also as reported by the same LF partner, ABDC Ltd, the total volume of collected honey has increased from 850 kg (2019 season) to 1,200 kg equivalent to 44.1% increase (ABDC Ltd September 2020 monthly report).
No indicator available - only a description of the activity results is published
